comments.commentBody:
'...Should assistance go to people with hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of assets?...'

In NYC, these homes would go for $500-1M+ and it is insane that the homeowners do not rent out apartments in there 3-4 floor brownstones or sell them and live within their means, but feel free to ask the rest of us, 70% of whom are renters, to subsidize their mortgages.

I do agree and am not as heartless as some of the posters who merely counsel HEAP recipients to move. Relocating, particularly, at a later stage in life, is not as easy as some make it sound. People tend to move to places where they have friends and family. Not everyone has social connections in some of the cheaper locales mentioned, e.g., Texas.

I would think giving folks, say, three consecutive years of assistance should be enough for them to realize that, hey, this isn't working out, and I need to create some other options.

I also agree with the other poster that the city should attach a non-interest bearing lien on the property to recover HEAP payments when the property is sold.

These two conditions seem more than fair.

Should assistance go to people with hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of assets? That's a great question.

I think everyone--rich or poor--deserves compassion and assistance in a crisis, but those with assets should have limits placed on how often they can qualify for assistance.

If you have assets and you need assistance at least once a year, you are living beyond your means. That's not good for you, it's ultimately not sustainable and it's not right to ask others to subsidize your ownership.

Dweb oh the horror! Business people in business for making money. Maybe the only "fair" way is for they to pay you to attend the performance.  Who held the gun to your head and forced to buy the tickets?

I don't understand what you are upset about. You purchased tickets on the day they went on sale and got them for face value. Sure, it took a little while, but that's because others were calling, too. I'm not sure what you think was so terrible about what happened.

I'm betting that the reason the agency didn't tell you the seat locations is because they didn't have the seats yet. They were probably going to buy them on the same day you did. Never buy from agencies if there are seats otherwise available.

Deep thanks on behalf of the millions of us who have been raped by ticket agencies and their collusion with venues and producers and scalpers.

We recently tried to get tickets to take a grand daughter to a performance of Wicked in Pittsburgh in January. They were on sale through agencies in the fall but not through the theater until early November. We started with the agencies and halted when we found that three tickets would cost us well over 300 dollars PLUS the "convenience fee which added another nearly 30% to the cost. Worse yet, you had no idea where your seats were until after you gave them your credit card information.

We waited until November and went through the theater....started at 9 in the morning and used three different lines continually calling. Got through once early and got hung up on....got through after an hour and got three tickets at about $325.

The only fair and honest way to handle these is through a lottery. You decide what section you want to be in and when and it is luck of the draw whether you get in. If there were justice, the states would be prosecuting the agencies and the venues for price fixing and collusion.

DYT, I feel your pain. I am not defending what is going on here courtesy of the NYT coders, but please try to keep this in mind.

There are at least 4 browsers that have enough users to warrant regression testing. Each of these browsers has at least 3 versions in common use. So now we have 9 browsers running on possibly 6 versions of Windows (for desktop PC's), 3 versions of MAC OS X, plus myriad IPads, Nooks, Kindles, and whatnot tablets. On the PC side, there are 17 Intel processors that run on 52 motherboards and 13 AMD processors that run on 9 motherboards. You can't even begin to count Android and IOS flavors.

My point is this: In spite of every standard that exists for every aspect of the internet and operating systems and hardware. There never has been and there probably never will be 100% compliance, let alone regression testing of each of the millions of configurations that exist in the world today. The best way to ensure the highest level of compliance, but not necessarily 100%, is to get a Macintosh or a Surface.

Whoever is running things at any IT shop these days has a thankless, impossible job. IMHO, the NYT crew just bit off more than they could chew and now we all have to wait until the meal is digested.

All of which should have been spotted before by everybody, everyone agreeing it had to be altered before competition could proceed. Perfect example of a situation where the only thing needed was one person standing tall, and no one did.

After the accident happened, seeing the photos of the row of steel support columns alongside the track was bad enough. How could any designer or engineer not clearly see how potentially lethal those columns were?

Almost worse was seeing photos of what was done to supposedly make the area safer after the accident. A scant and crude retaining wall was hastily erected on the track facing side of the columns. Featuring what appeared to be ordinary building materials assembled rather haphazardly by unskilled workers, the modification looked like the type of flimsy temporary partition walls one often encounters as part of airport remodeling projects. All in all, an utterly appalling absence of regard for safety and the value of the competitors' lives.

"One person one vote" is one of the grossest misrepresentations this malapportioned nation makes.

All the comments here seem to speak about the collective outrage we all feel. The article indicates this is an issue that transcends party lines.

Therefore, why are we (meaning everyone who feels galled by the Washington status quo) not sending letters and writing petitions to our House members demanding they make a change? Stop protecting your staffers and aides at the expense of the people you represent. Doesn't matter if you congressman/woman is a Democrat or Republican.

Let us stop trying to point fingers on "corporations" and "ultra-rich" alone. Lobbyists will represent anyone with money, whether it is a foundation, interest group or labor union. The inherent problem is that the members of Congress are unwilling to police themselves or their staffers. Let's face it, the Washington, DC metro area and suburbs probably house more of the 1% than anywhere else in the nation!

We should demand a 10 year complete ban on lobbying, without exceptions. Call/write your Congressman today!

As citizens, we all have a right to contact our representatives, whether we are CEO's of corporations or unemployed & living on charity.

99% of us, however, cannot hire a full time staff of people to live in Washington, develop relationships with lawmakers, slip them bribes, write legislation for them, & promise them lucrative jobs when they quit politics. But democracy is premised on the idea that we all have an equal say in government. One person, one vote. To make that happen, it seems to me we would either have to publicly fund lobbyists to represent regular people, to influence the lawmakers who were supposed to be representing us in the first place without being lobbied to do so. Or we would have to just make professional lobbying, along with other forms of bribery, patronage & influence peddling, illegal. I wonder why none of our representatives have thought of that...

Dr. K.

This account of Argentina's situation & your "Talking Troubled Turkey" column were excellent & instructive -- they are a tour de force in tutorial writing. It has me convinced that the greatest national priority for the U.S. should be to exercise its economic leadership by focusing on restoring the strength of the U.S. economy & our market.

I believe that you understand the mysteries of economic growth to chart a course for US monetary & fiscal policies & to convincingly support your recommendations.

Your advice on international policies, which would stop the shortening intervals between economic crises & your basis for facing the specter of "secular stagnation", would be taken seriously.

I accept as logically intuitive that savings has exceeded the volume of investments worth taking. Therefore, I recommend that your list of topics to discuss & solicit ideas should include investments, which will be broadly beneficial & will address the imperative of greenhouse gas emissions, replacing environmentally degrading industrial processes with new inventions, improving food & water security, and making the efficiency of electric power, decent housing, good public health and sanitation affordable & broadly available.

Not exactly the Four Freedoms or a complete list, but it is time for capitalism to be adapted to fit the realistic requirements for the survival of our species. This should create good paying jobs for all & handsome ROI on current dormant capital.

"They would not thrive in an overcrowded classroom with a teacher who texts in class, plays favorites, doesn't grade work or hand it back in a timely fashion."

I don't think our kids should be the pawns in someone else's mediocrity. Why should even a resilient child have to abide this?

It's not even about preparing them for crappy bosses, either. We either pay tuition or taxes and a certain level of adequacy is required.

"...how do I help my child survive the rest of the year with below-average teachers?"

This says TEACHERS, plural...sound like a bigger problem! I wonder where are all the homeschool advocates? I am not one, necessarily, as I think some pull their kids out of school too soon, but on the other hand I've been really pleased with my child's school. I fear I would not know what to do in this situation and the advice seems a little weak...telling the kid to stick it out, get used to it because they may have a bad boss someday, etc. That's great for adults, I suppose, but they need to be LEARNING now and whether we pay tuition to a private school or pay taxes, I don't think its unreasonable for parents to have the expectation that their kids are being taught and treated fairly.

You might want to learn to spell PRINCIPAL before you criticize teachers.  Most schools do not have a way for teachers to sit in on other teachers lessons--we are all teaching at the same time and likely doing other kinds of school-related jobs during our free periods.  What if there is only one class of each grade-where should the child be transferred to? Or if there is more than one class, likely they are all full.  Listen, I am a teacher and I am really good at my job and it bothers me a great deal when lousy teachers make us all look bad.  There are lousy teachers in my school too, and it breaks my heart for those kids whose time is just wasted.  Texting in class for any reason is totally unprofessional, even if there is a sick kid at home.  Get someone else to check in or wait until your lunch break.  If the teacher is tenured, there is nothing the principal can do.  And for this we have unions to thank (I am not in a teachers union--think they're terrible).  If we (teachers) want to be treated like professionals, we should act like professionals-dress feel, speak articulately, be active community members, lifelong learners ourselves, generally positive people, not slackers.  It's not an impossible job, it's a really rewarding one.

To be fair, there is not a religion on earth that does not consider its way to be the only true path to salvation. And, ironically - despite the "chosen people" moniker - Judaism is different in this regard. Judaism does not regard adherence to Jewish law - or membership in the Jewish religion - to be necessary for salvation or a favored place in the world to come. Rather, simply leading an ethical or moral life is sufficient for the non-Jew. Jews are "chosen" only in the sense that adherence to various extra commandments (such as dietary law) is required of them. It is ironic that the religion with the most inclusive concept of salvation is reviled as non-inclusive by the ignorant and bigoted.

Dylan, this is a very powerful piece of writing. I wish you healing. I am sure that your piece will help the survivors of child abuse.

Did society fail you? I'd disagree. While we are prepared to believe you, a definitive societal verdict can't be rendered in the absence of a criminal trial.

While the system is far from perfect, your case was investigated, you were believed, and you were removed from contact with your father. Your mother, sisters and brothers terminated contact with your father, too. That might not be a perfect solution, but you can say that you were ultimately believed, protected and cherished by the people who matter to you most.

Again, I wish you healing.
